dialogues.text: Emma watches on the wall, an official Ministry film of ma English countryside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had a series of bizarre weather reports.   We kept them hush-hush and sent agents into  the field for data. Case number one:  April 14, 3:35 P.M., Special Agent Simkins  investigating mysterious fires in corn circles.   A field outside the village of Little Snoring,  one of the hottest days of the year. Trapped  by a sudden blizzard. Found frozen to death  in a giant ice cube -- like a mammoth in  perma-frost. (the picture changes) Case two: Pilot Raymond Shaw, May 6, 11:28 A.M.  Took off from a deserted airstrip near Stoke Poges,  investigating bizarre atmospheric reports. A freak  rainstorm downed him. Knocked unconscious by a  flying fish, falling from 15,000 feet. Twenty-five  inches of rain in eight minutes, over an area the size  of a cricket pitch ... (the picture changes) ... Case three: June 2, 5:43 P.M. Defense Chief  Major Courtnay. Remains discovered in a turnip  field near Ashby de la Zouche. Our boffins  recorded a sudden blast of heat. Scorched earth,  temperature of 1000 degrees. Spontaneous  combustion. Not much of him left ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your research into climate engineering was  state-of-the-art. Your experiments could  have revolutionized our knowledge of global  warming -- had they succeeded. We need  your expertise.

dialogues.text: Perhaps I ought to talk with Dr.  Darling.

dialogues.text: A gallery of portraits of Emma Peel projected on the wall (1964) -- Poignant, inscrutable, fascinating, iconic -- b The swirling newspaper dots cover Mother and Steed like b As DR. DARLING, head of the Ministry's Psychological Oper kind of spy version of Timothy Leary, briefs them. In his Darling's obsessive interest in Emma adds a sinister air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One key point: Mrs. Peel is a widow: she's obsessively devoted to the memory  of her husband the scientist Peter Peel.  You may find her a little ... remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images of Peter Peel on the wall.  Of Emma with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were a team. Met at Cambridge.  Working on a top secret research mission  into weather conditions, code name The Prospero Project, when Peel died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steed looks meaningfully at Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something went wrong. System malfunction.   Explosion. Mrs. Peel had a narrow escape.   Suspected sabotage. Nothing proven. File  still open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you took so much interest in her, Dr. Darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband was one of ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes Peel's photo, then Mother) Peel? Did she know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still doesn't. Better safe than sorry.  She  was in a dangerous game, Steed. High  stakes. She may prove to be a risk.  If  she is, there's only one solution.  Termination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone particular in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Steed's reaction.  CLASHING BLADES OVER ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steed and Emma (new outfit), cross swords.  Like everythi champion.  Steed is hard put.  Both fence attached to cab dueling ... Steed is in white; Emma (natch), in black ... yin and yan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lady of hidden talents, Mrs. Peel ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tic-tac ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no intention of hiding them ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tic-tac ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scientist ... (tic-tac) ... marksman ... (tic-tac) ... swordsman ... (tic-tac) ... To what do you attribute your  overachievements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast swordplay.  Tic-tac-tic-tac-tic.  Steed's good, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father always wanted a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  I fail to see the connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a feeling you would. Touche!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lunges; her foil tips right into the heart on Steed's his mask; holds her foil tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take your point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma takes off her mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes indeed. I need protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Trubshaw's of Jermyn Street, since 1756."  Steed's Jag p there's a space.  Getting out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were on our way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, absolutely, but Trubshaw's a man  worth meeting. No point setting out  half shod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry) Or half cocked.

dialogues.speaker: TRUBSHAW
dialogues.text: slips Steed's hand-made shoes an.  The "lasts" shapes of Steed's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't agree more. Thank you,  Trubshaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly) Very good, Mr. Steed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bull moose's antlers.  A horned rhino.  A Leopard.  A t wall of hunting trophies Emma paces impatiently beneath t in tails and wing-collars, very old school tie.  Steed em waistcoat ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gags at the waistcoat) Steed, we really must be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relishing his shoes) Ahh. Perfect fit. The luxury of a  hand-made shoe. As unique as a face  or a fingerprint. Or should I say DNA?

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND DISPLAY
dialogues.text: Eyes watching Emma and Steed rise ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can but I wish you wouldn't ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Trubshaw ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A youngish man -- in black polo neck, Beatle-cut mop, pau high-pitched giggle.  BAILEY, a cocky, cool psychopath. Emma leave ... ... and saunters after them ...  CAR ROAR OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Jag races through them, heading for the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That place is so absurd, so out of date ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think so?

dialogues.text: reading:  "Scotland" with an arrow, as Steed and Emma zoo

dialogues.text: opens, revealing a tea service: a samovar of tea, feeding pouring into two china cups ... WIDEN to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steed's JAG BACKFIRES again as at the beginning ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. This car -- and you. Nobody walks around like that. Milk?

dialogues.text: Not all Tradition is bad, Mrs. Peel. No thank you.

dialogues.text: But why? What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Gentleman has to have a code. This is part of mine. A uniform. Think of it as my suit of shining armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I suppose you're the knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most unpredictable piece on the board. And always ready to protect his queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's predictable. When I find a queen in need of protection I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steed looks in the mirror.  Behind them, a car.  Tailing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hoping you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his foot down.  Zoom ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towards picturesque Scotland.  The JAG ROARS by - then th

dialogues.text: Emma consults a list, reads --

dialogues.text: Sir August Merryweather ... why are we seeing him first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As per mother's instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we always follow Mother's instructions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a man in my position --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what is your position, if you don't  mind my asking.  How did a stuffed  shirt like you get into this line of work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) They call me in when they've reached a  dead end. Freelance. Like yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no choice. Why should you risk your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After our fencing match, I was rather  hoping you would do the risking.   More tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma takes in Steed's evasive answers.  Sighing, she pour

dialogues.text: The Jag winds around Loch Ness, followed by the car.

dialogues.text: According to Mother, Sir August owns  half of the Highlands. A millionaire.   Former head of Special Projects at the  Ministry. Now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eccentric recluse?

dialogues.text: Not so much eccentric. More barking  mad. He has a wife called June. And  a daughter somewhere -- Julie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June, July ... August?

dialogues.text: The family does seem to be somewhat  meteorologically inclined.

dialogues.text: Any other vices?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of a piece, really. A fanatical  weatherman. Chairman of BROLLY. (off her look) British Royal Organisation For Lasting Liquid Years. Thinks British  weather has been tampered with  by ... aliens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ... I distract him while you snoop  around? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small talk.  Try the weather.

dialogues.text: Steed and Emma speed up to the huge open main gates Signs:  "Private: No Admittance."  Guards in hunting gear rifles.  They start up the drive ... Several peacocks on the lawn fan open their beautiful tai One of them, a mechanical peacock whose thousand eyes CLI CAMERA ... The other car pulls in behind. Inside, reveal Bailey watc

dialogues.text: of semi-tropical climate.  Jungle plants, parakeets, snak cabinets and bell jars:  stuffed birds, butterflies, spid 100 degrees with high humidity. The Butler leaves. Emma fans herself.  Nobody in the roam.  But hears a soun smoked glass conservatory.

dialogues.text: Sir August ... ? Sir August ... ?

dialogues.text: Eh? In here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma follows the SOUND, steps cautiously forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beneath a sprinkler system of torrential rain, an old man Emma stays cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to apply for membership in Brolly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts above the tempest) You don't get rain like you used to in  England. A good shower that's the ticket.   Stiffens resolve, puckers the spirit, quells  the namby-pamby in a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR AUGUST steps out of the shower and wind machine.  A b flippers, goggles.  He starts to disrobe, the NOISE DIES

dialogues.text: I so agree. How did you acquire a  taste for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out in India. So character-forming for the  British. Not the heat. Good Lord, no. The  rain, dash it. A good monsoon. Fifteen  inches overnight. A whole week of lovely  rain. I remember one summer in Jaipur ...

dialogues.text: Sir August removes his goggles, recognizes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You

dialogues.text: Have we met?

dialogues.text: You mean you don't recall??

dialogues.text: Ah, Lady June ...

dialogues.text: Emma's attention switches to LADY JUNE, a buxom lady in a who wheels in a tray of scones.

dialogues.text: Dear August.  Loves his showers. Like a baby. (beat) Scones, Mrs. Peel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lady -- June ...

Starts to blink Surrounded by thick purple haze Steed stumbles and falls Down a hill.  Tumbles to the bottom.  He knocks his head shakes his head.  Eyes refocus.  He sees

It wilts. He arrives at the phone box. Opens the door.  Steed picks listens to -- A SCRATCHY ORCHESTRAL RECORDING of "The Merry Widow."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: You were very lucky.  Four shots to  the heart. I found you after I slipped  away from Sir August. Mother brought  you here. Not me you should thank.

dialogues.text: I wasn't about to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean your man Trubshaw.  Your bullet-proof waistcoat.  I thought  you were just overdressed.

dialogues.text: I might say the same.

dialogues.text: Mother with Dr. Darling taking notes.  Emma looks up at t But they both are wearing headphones.

dialogues.text: Mother and Dr. Darling have me  under observation. They think I  tried to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should they think that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told them. You said I arrived  on a camel, shot you four times.  Left you for dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly that's how I remember it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's absurd. I may not be  over-fond of you, Steed, but it's  not my style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps your memory plays tricks, Mrs. Peel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conceding) That's possible. Sir August was convinced  he'd met me before. But I'd never met him.   Another odd thing. When it rained, he said  it was just as someone had promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But he must know. Incidentally,  my double left you with this.

dialogues.text: You mean my other self ...

dialogues.text: A boardroom suite, overlooking London.  Lights twinkling Around a conference table.  Twelve TEDDY BEARS.  Each six and sinister.  In pink, turquoise, brown, black, white, g ears, swivel eyes.  One teddy sports a familiar tartan .. On the table, children's party food: jellies, hundreds an And wrapped presents before each. Each bear has a name-badge: Bobby, Bobo, Bruno, Bibi, Bet their fur.  A children's tune, "THE TEDDY BEAR'S PICNIC," a gavel rapping order. A distinctively chilling voice, eerily familiar and seduc story --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Murmurs of congratulations amongst the bears ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) You have all given time, money and expertise  to achieve our goal. But we are reaching a  new phase of our operation. From today,  many of you will no longer be needed. I have  to warn you ...

dialogues.text: Dismay from the teddy bears.  As a CUCKOO CLOCK RINGS OUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) A cuckoo.  The first sign of spring, and ...  A cuckoo in our nest. Our organization is  no longer secret. Agents are investigating  us. Their names are John Steed and Emma  Peel. I believe we have a traitor among us  ... perhaps more than one ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uproar from the teddy bears.  Shouts of "Who?" (*PS: One rabbit who seems especially alarmed).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) That remains to be seen. When we find  the traitors, they will be dealt with severely. TEDDY BEAR #l These agents.  Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Here. In this building. By our estimate, they  will enter this room in thirty-five point five  seconds precisely ...

We thought of injecting a  chemical cocktail into the atmosphere  by laser and satellite. A 'quick fix'...
